courses.subject: ARAB
courses.title: Arabic I
courses.description: As the first in a series of language courses, this course invites students without prior knowledge of Arabic to explore the basic features of Modern Standard Arabic. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will receive intensive practice in spoken and written Arabic through interactive class work, homework and online exercises. They will become familiar with the basic concepts of Arabic grammar and learn how to interact in some simple everyday situations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARAB2000,2001,2050,3000 or 3050
courses.course_syllabus:
| Course Content | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Unit | Speech Acts | Grammar | Culture |
| 1 - 3 | Reading Arabic words | * Short introduction to Arabic language * The Arabic alphabet - isolated/ initial / medial / final * The short vowels * Tanween * Sukon | History of Arabic Language and people Using The vowels in the History of the Arabic Language |
| 4 - 9 | Useful Expressions | * The long vowels * Shadda * Alif Maqsura * Hamza * Masculine and Feminine nouns * Definite article | Arabic Kitchen (Famous dishes and drinks) |
| 10 - 13 | * Introduce yourself * Meet someone for first time * Asking about names * Introduce your family | * Singular demonstrative pronouns * Singular personal pronouns * Conjunction * Singular attached pronouns | Arabic Anthology (Selected Works) |
| 14 | * What do you do? * Where are you from? * Where do you work or study? * Describing things | * Interrogative particles * Relative pronouns * Adjectives * Prepositions * Simple nominal sentence in Arabic | Contributions of Arabs in World Heritage |
courses.feedback_evaluation: Our language programme highly values students’ feedback and comments and is happy to use them for reflection on our teaching and improvement. Students are very welcome to provide comments and feedback on the course any time to their course teacher or the course level coordinator through email or in personal conversation. In addition, students’ feedbacks will be collected in the middle of the term through an open-end questionnaire and the teacher will discuss the feedbacks in class and make improvements if necessary. The course will also follow the university’s course evaluation exercise at the end of the term, and students’ feedbacks will be used for future course planning and teaching.
courses.required_readings: Ta‘allamu Al-‘arabiya (Learn Arabic Language). REFAI Amjad. Self-Published, 2016. ISBN 978-9887773900.

- Faruk Abu-Chacra. Arabic: An Essential Grammar. London and New York: Routledge, 2007. Paperback, 355 pages. ISBN 978-0-415-41571-2. (Hong Kong Public library call number 492.7 ABU).

courses.subject: ARAB
courses.title: Arabic II
courses.description: Building on the knowledge acquired in ARAB1000, this course aims to further develop students’ ability to communicate in Arabic in various everyday situations. It also seeks to give students a taste of Arabic culture and invites them to explore cultural differences. Through intensive practice students will develop more confidence in interacting in Arabic while further expanding and solidifying their understanding of the basic grammar and pronunciation patterns.

courses.subject: ARAB
courses.title: Arabic III
courses.description: This course aims to further enhance students’ communication skills in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Students are expected to communicate confidently in a wider range of social interactions including more formal situations and simple professional contexts as well as reporting past events and sharing experience. At the end of this course, students will have completed a proficiency level comparable to level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite: ARAB2000 or 2050
Not for students who have taken ARAB3000 or 3050
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Course Content** | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Lesson** | **Topic** | **Function** | **Vocabulary** | **Grammar** |
| 9 | The Weather is Nice | Describe weathers | Seasons, weathers, degrees | Negative form |
| 10 | Eid Mubarak | Talk about Arabic dates and holidays, describe feelings and expressions | Holidays, months and dates, feelings, expressions, special greetings | Conditional tense |
| 11 | What’s Your Plan for This Weekend? | Ask and talk about future plans and leisure activities | Habits, leisure activities | Conjunctions |
| 12 | Let’s Go Traveling | Book a hotel, buy transportation tickets, ask for direction | Hotel terms, transportation terms, directions | Interrogative pronouns |

courses.subject: ARAB
courses.title: Arabic I & II
courses.description: This is a summer intensive Arabic language course for beginners, covering the full syllabus of ARAB1000 and 2000.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARAB1000,2000,2001,3000 or 3050
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Course Content** | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Lesson** | **Topic** | **Function** | **Vocabulary** | **Grammar** |
| 1 | Letters | The pronunciations, marks and writings of the letters. | Twenty-eight letters | Marks, ways of writing. |
| 2 | Greetings | The ways of greeting in Islamic way and normal way. | Basic ways of greeting | Masculine, feminine, singular, plural. Linked pronouns |
| 3 | Meeting New People | Ask and give personal information. | Greetings in different times, jobs, numbers, names. | Separated pronouns |
| 4 | Shopping | Ask for prices, describe colors, sizes, and positions of things. | Clothes, colors, big sums, sizes, place prepositions. | Present tense |
| 5 | A Date for Dinner | Talk on the phone, make an appointment. | Days of the week, time, meals, doing things, places. | Suggestions |
| 6 | At the Dinner Table | Offer helps, describe foods. | Dining wares, meats, Arabic food names, tastes, temperature descriptions. | Possessive verbs |
| 7 | Knowing the Neighbors | Ask about and describe others’ outlooks and present statuses. | Appearance features, marriage statuses, ages, school grades, school subjects, kin terms. | Past tense, future tense |
| 8 | Transportation & Location | The use of transportations, describe locations. | Vehicles, locations, places. | Passive voice |
courses.feedback_evaluation:
The evaluation process of the course will be conducted in the following manner:
• 1 mid-term evaluation and collection of qualitative feedback from student panels/ forums/ internet forums
• 1 end-of-term course evaluation with statistics and open comments from students regarding the course’s strengths and areas of improvements
